reviewText: As a fan of Warren William I had to check out SMARTY. The following review is for that movie alone, I didn't watch MERRY WIVES OF RENO. Beware, there are also spoilers ahead. According to the recent released excellent biography of William, Warren William: Magnificent Scoundrel of Pre-Code Hollywood, Warren considered this to be one of his worst films, with which author John Stangeland heartily agrees. Having now watched it myself, make that three. The basic plot revolves around Warren's marriage to Joan Blondell (Gold Diggers Of 1933,The Cincinnati Kid) who is the personification of a smart-a** and chop-buster. She takes perverse pleasure in driving Warren crazy, constantly questioning his manhood. During an evening of bridge with their friends, including Edward Everett Horton (Here Comes Mr. Jordan,Rocky & Bullwinkle: Fractured Fairy Tales), as a lawyer who's totally crushed out on her, she pushes Warren to the edge and he slaps her. A divorce and marriage to Horton ensues, devastating Warren but not Joan, who treats it all as a lark. As expected (if you've ever seen a movie), when Warren finally gets over it Joan, bored with wimpy (did he ever play any other kind of role?) Everett, plots to get him back. Blondell actually gets Horton mad enough to slap her to move her plan along. At the end, after they make up she baits him again and he slaps her. This time though she's happy, because he's proved to her that he's a "real man!" To quote Stangeland; "did I mention this is a comedy?" Originally titled "Hit Me Again," one of the pressbook's suggestions to exhibitors was to plant a newspaper article titled "Most Women Need A Good Sock Once And A While!" Filmed just after the Production Code went into effect, trying to get the idea across that Blondell "gets off" on physical abuse would have at least been tackled head-on during the Pre-Code era. Unfortunately a more adapt title for this sorry mess would've been SMARMY...... Other much better Warren William films include: Beauty And The Boss,Perry Mason Mysteries: The Original Warner Bros. Movies Collection,Lady For A Day,Arizona,The Wolf Man

Not burned on M-DISC.  Instead, they used the old-fashioned, obsolete DVD-R that last only about five years.

With M-DISC, you could expect a 1000 year lifetime.  I would've gladly paid two dollars more to have these movies burned on M-DISC.

The movies themselves I liked, good video, and audio quality, 4.5 Stars.
Both features  are hidden gems from the pre code era.  Warners knew how to do it. Highly recommended.

I love the set of movies starring Joan Blondell and Glenda Farrell, and that includes Merry Wives of Reno. It's light entertainment to be sure, but it's very comfortable and amusing. The second movie, "Smarty," with Blondell but no Glenda Farrell, is also entertaining if somewhat bizarre. You can't go wrong with this DVD. BTW, there's a Blondell/Farrell movie out there that isn't available yet; "Kansas City Princess." If anyone in power reads this, please make that movie available.

I bought this DVD for Smarty because I like Margaret Lindsay, but I enjoyed merry Wives Of Reno very much. Joan Blondell is SOOO good-looking!

These are two good entertaining B movies ,not classics but good fun.
Joan Blondell never looked better than she does in the little black dress she wears in a good part of Smarty.
Guy Kippee is very funny in Merry Wives of Reno.
